long.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: measuring a great length from one end to the other
long.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: the longest tunnel in the world
He stretched out his long legs.
long.translation[0].definitions[1].defin: continuing or travelling a great distance from one place to another
long.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: Springfield is a long way from Chicago.
Liz lives in Cheltenham, which is a long way away.
It’s a long walk to the shops from here.
long.translation[0].definitions[2].defin: continuing for a large amount of time, or for a larger amount of time than usual
long.translation[0].definitions[2].examp: She’s recovering from a long illness.
Doctors often work long hours (=work for more time than is usual).
There was a long silence before anybody spoke.
It took me the longest time to figure out how to open the windows.
He’s been gone a long time.
I haven’t been there for a long while.
It took a long time to get everything ready.
She died a long time ago.
long.translation[0].definitions[3].defin: used to talk or ask about a particular length, distance, or time
long.translation[0].definitions[3].examp: The cable is not quite long enough.
The speech was twenty minutes long.
long.translation[0].definitions[4].defin: containing a lot of words, letters, names, or pages
long.translation[0].definitions[4].examp: He has a very long name.
He owes money to a list of people as long as your arm (=a very long list).
long.translation[0].definitions[5].defin: covering all of your arms or legs
long.translation[0].definitions[6].defin: making you feel tired or bored
long.translation[0].definitions[7].defin: a long vowel in a word is pronounced for a longer time than a short vowel with the same sound
long.translation[0].note_box[0].items[1]: I had a nice long bath
I had a long nice bath
long.translation[0].note_box[0].items[2]: She wore a long black coat
She wore a black long coat
long.translation[0].note_box[1].sections: continuing for a long time
The film was very long.
There has been a long period without rain.
lengthy
continuing for a long time, especially longer than you want or expect
Drivers face lengthy delays on all roads out of the city.
Police are going through the lengthy process of re-examining all the evidence.
He faces a lengthy prison sentence.
long-running
continuing for a long time – used especially about disputes, campaigns, or shows
He has been involved in a long-running dispute with his neighbour.
The programme is one of the longest-running series on television.
a long-running campaign to prevent the airport from being built
long-lasting
continuing for a long time – used especially about effects or relationships
Stress can have long-lasting effects.
While at the school, she made many long-lasting friendships.
protracted
continuing for a long time, especially an unusually long time
Despite protracted negotiations, they were unable to reach an agreement.
The couple have been involved in a protracted battle for custody of their children.
prolonged
continuing for a long time, especially longer than expected, or longer in a way that makes a situation worse
He returned to work after a prolonged absence.
Studies have linked prolonged use of the drug to cancer.
a prolonged period of economic decline
extended
continuing for a long time – used especially about visits, trips, breaks etc that last longer than was planned
an extended stay in hospital
He took an extended break from work after his father died.
She didn’t like being away from home for extended periods.
lasting
strong enough or great enough to continue for a long time
The negotiations were aimed at achieving a lasting peace.
This affair has done lasting damage to the president’s credibility.
The book left a lasting impression on me.
enduring
continuing for a long time – used especially about memories, influences, or feelings of liking someone or something
One of my most enduring memories is of going on holiday to France with my parents.
the enduring appeal of Conan Doyle’s stories
his enduring love for Ireland
marathon
continuing for a very long time and needing a lot of energy, patience, or determination
It was a marathon session of talks which continued until 3 am.
He arrived after a marathon journey across Europe.
too long
long-winded
continuing for too long – used about speeches, answers, explanations etc
a very long-winded answer to a simple question
He gave a long-winded speech about the company’s vision for the future.
interminable
very long and boring
They faced an interminable wait in the departure lounge of the airport.
The journey seemed interminable.
long-drawn-out
used about a process that continues for much too long
The news heightened expectations that the long-drawn-out investigation might be coming to a close.
long.translation[1].definitions[0].examp: Reform of the law is long overdue.
long.translation[1].definitions[1].defin: used to ask and talk about particular amounts of time
long.translation[1].definitions[1].examp: How long will it take to get there?
Try to keep going for as long as possible.
It took me longer than I thought it would.
long.translation[1].definitions[2].defin: at a time that is a long time before or after a particular time
long.translation[1].definitions[2].examp: It wasn’t long before (=soon) Lisa arrived.
This all happened long before you were born.
He should have left her long ago.
long.translation[2].definitions[0].defin: to want something very much, especially when it seems unlikely to happen soon
long.translation[2].definitions[0].examp: He longed to see her again.
She longed for the chance to speak to him in private.
She longed for him to return.
long for somebody to do something
long.translation[4].definitions[0].defin: possessing shares, bonds, currencies etc because you believe that their value is going to increase
long.translation[4].definitions[0].examp: Those who were long on dollars rushed to sell them.
long.translation[4].definitions[1].defin: if you work long hours or a long day, you work for more time than is usual
long.translation[4].definitions[1].examp: Tax specialists often work long hours during assessment time.
long.translation[5].definitions[0].defin: to buy or keep bonds, shares, currencies etc because you believe that their value will rise
long.translation[5].definitions[0].examp: He reversed short positions and went long on Hong Kong stocks.
Dealers are going long on dollars in expectation of today’s release of strong US trade figures.
